section.title: Introduction [Handler Objects]
section.para: A handler object exists for each base resource. Each handler object provides methods to create, retrieve, update, and delete resources and their subresources. With the exception of the create method, all methods require a unique identifier to select a single resource.

listitem.para: Retrieve method: Returns the XML representation of a resource.
Create method: Takes the XML representation of a resource and returns the XML representation of the created resource.
Update method: Takes the XML representation of a resource and returns the XML representation of the updated resource.

section.para: Each handler object defines a service interface which is described in the WSDL. For exception handling, method names, and information about retrieving the service description, see the interface specification of the resources.

formalpara.title: Exception handling
formalpara.para: SOAP uses WSDL definitions of the services. The WSDL definitions specify how the request and the response of a service must look, including possible exceptions. There are various tools on the market that can generate Java objects out of a WSDL (for example, wsdl2java from the axis-framework). The response can automatically populate these Java objects by binding them to the specific responses. This enables an application to work with objects and not with XML. A Java application can now directly handle the eSciDoc exceptions by catching the generated exceptions. For further information on error and exception handling inside the infrastructure, please refer to the section on exception handling - - and to the WSDL files that are provided.

section.title: Access to the Resource Handlers
section.para: All supported resources are accessible via SOAP. All available methods to manipulate a certain resource via SOAP are described in the document dedicated to this resource. Each resource offers its own SOAP service and has a WSDL interface description - for example, the methods of the item resource are accessible by the ItemHandlerService. The names of these services are listed in the description of the SOAP calls of the methods.

section.title: Working with Subresources
section.para: Every resource offers the facility to access its data by addressing subresources. For example, it is possible to retrieve and update a single metadata record of an item instead of retrieving and updating the whole item to correct a typo in the title.

To achieve the best performance in working with the eSciDoc infrastructure and to minimize the arising overhead, it is helpful to use the offered subresources to retrieve and update the required data.
